overview_of_class: This course is an introduction to the study and structure of film, television, and other audiovisual media. We will define and examine the expressive and aesthetic power of the basic elements of the moving image. Specifically, the course will investigate, across a variety of different media, modes, and historical periods, the fundamentals of cinematography, especially the shot and its composition; editing; set design, costume, and acting styles; and sound. We will also discuss narrative, genre, documentary, animation, and experimental film. The goal of the course is to acquaint students with a vocabulary specific to cinema and media analysis, and to provide students with the critical tools required for the accurate description and formal analysis of the moving image.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students in this course will be required to develop and demonstrate:
· Their familiarity with basic elements of cinematic language in theory and practice
· An understanding of the relationship between form and content, especially in terms of the way that media texts signify culturally
· A basic understanding of select theories and concepts in cinema and media studies

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be evaluated based upon in-class participation and attendance in lecture, screening and discussion sections, long (6-8 p) and short (400-600 words) written exercises, and a final exam.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
Required text: The Film Experience, Fourth Edition, by Timothy Corrigan and Patricia White

The class includes weekly in-class screenings; all assigned viewings are also made available on Canvas.
